questions.text: All of the following diseases are targeted by India for elimination in the future, except?
questions.explanation:
Diseases that have been eliminated from India.

DISEASE

YEAR

  

Leprosy

2005

Occurrence of less than 1 case per 10,000 at subnational and district level.

Maternal and neonatal tetanus

May, 2015

Occurrence of less than 1 case per 1,000 live births annually.

Polio

Last case in 2011
  • February 24, 2012

India was removed from the list of polio-endemic countries by WHO

  • March 27, 2014

India is certified polio-free by the Regional Certification Commission (RCC), WHO

Dracunculiasis

(Guinea worm infection)

2000

Zero cases continuously for three consecutive years.

Yaws

2004

Infectious trachoma

2017

Prevalence in children aged 1–9 years of less than 5%, sustained for at least two years without ongoing mass antibiotic treatment, in each formerly endemic district.

Diseases targeted to be eliminated from India.

DISEASE

TARGETED YEAR

  

Kala-azar

2023 by India

2030 by WHO

Incidence less than 1 case per 10,000 population at the Block PHC level.

Filariasis

2027 by India

2030 by WHO

Less than 1% microfilariae carrier rate

Measles

2023

Absence of endemic measles transmission in a defined geographical area > 12 months

HIV/AIDS

2024

  

Tuberculosis

2025

  

Malaria

2030

Zero indigenous cases and deaths due to malaria for 10 years in the whole country

Elimination of diseases in India

Eliminated Diseases

Targeted for elimination
  • Leprosy
  • Maternal and Neonatal tetanus
  • Polio
  • Dracunculiasis
  • Yaws
  • Infectious trachoma
  • Kala-azar
  • Filariasis
  • Measles
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Tuberculosis
  • Malaria

Note: In India, the target for eliminating kala azar was achieved in 2024 but has yet to be officially declared.

questions.text: Termination of all modes of transmission of which of the following has not been achieved?
questions.explanation:
Eradication of diseases in India

Eradicated Diseases

Targeted for eradication

  • Smallpox (1980)
  • Wild poliovirus 2 (2015)
  • Wild poliovirus 3 (2019)
  • Wild poliovirus 1
  • Measles
  • Dracunculiasis
  • Leprosy

questions.text: Match the following level of prevention with their correct definition. Level of prevention Definition 1) Primary a) Prevention of establishment of risk factors in a population. 2) Secondary b) Prevention of the development of disease in a high-risk group/individual. 3) Tertiary c) Prevention or limitation of disability in a diseased individual. 4) Primordial d) Prevention of the progression of diseases that are in their early stages.
questions.explanation:
Levels of prevention

Definition

Primordial

  • Prevention of establishment of risk factors.
  • It aims to discourage people from adopting harmful habits.
  • Avoiding smoking

Primary

  • Health promotion and specific protection.
  • Prevention of onset of disease in a high-risk group/individual.
  • It aims to protect the health of those who are at risk.
  • Reduces the incidence of the disease.
  • Quit smoking

Secondary

  • Disease progression can be prevented at an early stage (Disease is reversible).
  • It aims to reduce the prevalence of the disease by early identification and prompt treatment of diseases, and it also prevents complications.
  • Screening for diabetes.

Tertiary

  • Prevention or limitation of impairment and disability in a diseased patient who has developed complications due to the disease and the disease has become irreversible.
  • It aims to minimize a patient's suffering and maximize potential years of useful life.
  • Disability limitation and rehabilitation.

Quaternary
  • Prevention of the risk of overmedicalization of a patient or population.
  • Aims to prevent prescription of unnecessary medications and invasive medical interventions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mode of intervention for the secondary level of prevention?
Which of the following modes of intervention is not a primary level of prevention?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of MR vaccination to children

options.label: B
options.text: Examination of school students to identify signs of anemia

options.label: D
options.text: Implementing strict laws regarding drinking and driving

questions.correct_answer: B. Examination of school students to identify signs of anemia

questions.text: Choose the correct statements from the following: a)BCG vaccine for TB- primary b)BCG for Ca bladder- secondary c)OCP for contraception- primary d)OCP for PCOD- secondary
questions.explanation:
Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations (statement a)
  • Health education
  • Family planning (statement c)
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examination

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening
  • DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.
  • Treatment (statement b and d )

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery

questions.text: Arrange the following events in the correct sequence: Impairment Disability Functional Limitation Handicap Disease

In a rural village, trachoma remains a significant public health concern. A public health officer is tasked with implementing a comprehensive prevention strategy for trachoma. Match each intervention with the appropriate level of prevention: 1. Primary Prevention a. Coordinates surgical treatment for blindness 2. Secondary Prevention b. Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation. 3. Tertiary Prevention c. Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases. 4. Quaternary Prevention d. Conduct regular eye screenings.
questions.explanation:
Levels of Prevention

Description

Measures

Primary Prevention

Interventions before the onset of the disease to avert its occurrence by addressing the pre-pathogenesis phase.

Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation to prevent trachoma.

Secondary Prevention

Aim to halt disease progression in its early stages and prevent complications through timely diagnosis (e.g., screening, case-finding) and prompt, appropriate treatment.

Conduct regular eye screenings to detect and treat trachoma early.

Tertiary Prevention

Focuses on minimizing the impact of existing health conditions by reducing impairments and disabilities, alleviating suffering, and promoting adjustment to irreversible states.

Coordinates surgical treatment for those with trachoma-related blindness.

Quaternary Prevention

Promoting evidence-based practices to prevent over diagnosis and offering ethically validated treatment options

Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases to avoid unnecessary treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following interventions is an example of rehabilitation?

options.label: A
options.text: HPV vaccination in a reproductive-age woman.

options.label: B
options.text: Organising physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors.

options.label: D
options.text: Conducting regular screenings to detect early signs of diabetes-related neuropathy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Organising physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors.
questions.explanation:
Disability Limitation

Rehabilitation

Preventing progression from impairment to handicap.

Restoring and maximizing functional abilities.

Maintain the current level of function and prevent further deterioration.

Achieve the highest possible level of functional independence and quality of life.

Targeted medical treatment, assistive devices, and environmental modifications.

Coordinated multidisciplinary efforts (medical, social, educational, vocational).

E.g.

  • Medical treatment.
  • Assistive devices.
  • Environmental modifications.

E.g.

  • Organizing physical therapy sessions for stroke survivors.

questions.text: For which of the following diseases is mass prophylaxis more commonly employed than mass treatment?
questions.explanation:
Mass prophylaxis

Mass Treatment

Description

It involves administering preventive treatment to an entire population to prevent disease occurrence.

It involves treating an entire population or community to control or eliminate a disease.

Level of prevention

Primary prevention strategy.      (To prevent disease onset in individuals who have not yet been infected).

Secondary prevention strategy.     (Aim to reduce the prevalence of a disease and prevent further transmission).

Examples

Mass vaccination during outbreaks to prevent the spread of diseases such as:

  • Cholera
  • Hepatitis A
  • Lymphatic filariasis (Anti-filarial drugs)
  • Malaria (Anti-malarial drugs)
  • Onchocerciasis (Ivermectin)

questions.text: Which of the following international declarations or charters is primarily associated with outlining the principles and strategies for health promotion?
Which term describes the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data for the planning, implementing, and evaluating public health practices?
Which surveillance method involves routine reporting and data collection without active efforts to enhance reporting?
What is the main objective of evaluating healthcare establishments?

options.label: B
options.text: Assessing the efficacy and efficiency of health services

questions.correct_answer: B. Assessing the efficacy and efficiency of health services

questions.text: Which of the following measures is implemented for individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious?
